message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of autism spectrum disorder, and among the options, only CGG trinucleotide repeats on the X-chromosome is associated with the disorder. An additional X chromosome is associated with Klinefelter syndrome, and three copies of the same chromosome is associated with trisomy disorders. Defective phenylalanine hydroxlyase activity is associated with phenylketonuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical features suggest that the patient may have Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by a CGG trinucleotide repeat on the X-chromosome. An additional X chromosome (Klinefelter syndrome) would not explain the symptoms, while defective phenylalanine hydroxlyase activity (phenylketonuria) and three copies of the same chromosome (trisomy 21) have different clinical manifestations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical features suggest a diagnosis of Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by an abnormality in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome that results in an increased number of CGG trinucleotide repeats. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Options (A), (C), and (D) are not associated with Fragile X syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The described symptoms suggest autism spectrum disorder, and among the options, only CGG trinucleotide repeats on the x-chromosome are associated with this disorder, specifically fragile X syndrome, which is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability. The elongated facial features and large ears also support this diagnosis. An additional X chromosome suggests Klinefelter syndrome, which is not associated with these symptoms. Defective phenylalanine hydroxylase activity suggests phenylketonuria, which presents with different symptoms, and three copies of the same chromosome suggests Down syndrome, which presents with different physical characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have Fragile X syndrome, which is caused by the expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats on the X chromosome. An additional X chromosome (Option A) would suggest Klinefelter syndrome, which presents with different symptoms. Defective phenylalanine hydroxylase activity (Option C) would suggest Phenylketonuria, which presents with different symptoms as well. Three copies of the same chromosome (Option D) could suggest Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome, but the symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis.

An additional X chromosome would suggest Klinefelter syndrome. Defective phenylalanine hydroxylase activity would suggest phenylketonuria. Three copies of the same chromosome would suggest a chromosomal disorder such as Down syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest Autism Spectrum Disorder, which is often associated with Fragile X Syndrome. This is caused by an expansion of CGG repeats on the X chromosome. An additional X chromosome (Klinefelter Syndrome) is not a likely cause as the patient presents with elongated facial features which are not typically seen in Klinefelter Syndrome. Defective phenylalanine hydroxlyase activity (phenylketonuria) would not present with the symptoms described. Three copies of the same chromosome (Trisomy) is also not a likely cause as the patient has normal physical characteristics except for the elongated facial features.
